document.docAuthor: Chris J. Hodgson & Douglas J. Williams
document.masterDocTitle: (Hemiptera: Sternorrhyncha, Coccomorpha) with particular reference to species from the Afrotropical, western Palaearctic and western Oriental Regions, with the revival of Antecerococcus Green and description of a new genus and fifteen new species, and with ten new synonomies

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: (Hemiptera: Sternorrhyncha, Coccomorpha) with particular reference to species from the Afrotropical, western Palaearctic and western Oriental Regions, with the revival of Antecerococcus Green and description of a new genus and fifteen new species, and with ten new synonomies

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type details. GABON
, Ikoy-Banja, on
Musanga
sp., -.
vii. 1962
, C. Brunck. Depository: MNHN :
holotype
adf (MNHN No. 2832 - 2 );
paratype
adff, same data as holotype , 2 / 2 adff (MNHN 2832 - 1 ; MNHN 2832 - 3 ). Although Lambdin ( 1983 ) states that a paratype was deposited in the USNM, it is not there (Miller, pers. comm.)

Material studied. Paratype : GABON , Ikoy-Bandje, on
Musanga
sp. ( Urticaceae ), -.
vii. 1962
, Brunck (USNM): 1 / 1 adf (fâ€”distorted). Also : MALAWI , no other site information, on
Uapaca kirkiana
( Phyllanthaceae ,? 2000 , VKH 8 (BMNH): 2 / 5 adff (fâ€“g; previously identified as C. ?
theydoni
).
Note: main description taken from type specimen; data in [...] brackets for the specimens from Malawi .
Mounted material. Body roundly to oval pear-shaped, 2.15 [2.0â€“ 2.8 ] mm long, 1.67 [ 1.5â€“2.75 ] mm wide.

Dorsum. Eight-shaped pores of 3 or 4 sizes: (i) largest
17â€“20 x
8â€“12 [
16â€“
21 x 12â€“13
] Âµm, present in a submarginal line on posterior abdominal segments, each margin with a line of 6 pores posteriorly and a slightly more anterior group of 11â€“14 pores; (ii) slightly smaller large pores (each
16 x 12
[
15â€“
20 x 12â€“14
] Âµm), in swirls [more obvious in Malawi material] throughout most of dorsum apart from medially on posterior abdominal segments, but sparse or absent in a few clear areas; (iii) medium-sized 8 -shaped pores, each
10â€“12 x
5.0â€“ 5.5 [
8â€“10 x
5.0â€“ 5.5 ] Âµm, present associated with larger pore and also present in most clear areas and in bands across dorsum of posterior abdominal segments, where slightly smaller, each
8 x
4 [
8 x
3.0â€“ 3.5 ] Âµm; and (iv) a very small 8 - shaped pore, each 4.0â€“ 4.5 x 2.5 [
5 x
3 ] Âµm, usually present at apex of each disc-pore band, with 2 [ 1 or 2 ] per band. Simple pores very sparse throughout, each 3â€“5 Âµm wide. Cribriform plates of moderate size, slightly irregular in shape [occasionally fused?], each 16â€“20 [ 16â€“40 ] Âµm widest, with a fairly narrow sclerotized margin; in a submedial group of 4 [ 3â€“6 ] on each side of abdominal segment IV. Dorsal setae few near apex of each disc-pore band, each setose and about 10 Âµm long; usually with 2 associated with each anterior band and 1 with each posterior band. Tubular ducts each 25â€“27 Âµm long; outer ductule clearly wider than those on venter, abundant. Anal lobes membranous apart from inner margin which is distinctly sclerotized and slightly reticulated; each lobe about 100 [ 90 ] Âµm long with a long apical seta, each broken [ 225 +] Âµm long; dorsal fleshy setae short and stout and generally bent, each seta near apex 20â€“22 [ 25 ] Âµm long, more anterior fleshy setae longer and stouter, each 23 [ 25â€“32 ] Âµm long; ventral setae near apex stoutly setose, each 22 Âµm long ( 30 Âµm long); medioventral setae not detected [occasionally present and each 14â€“18 Âµm long]; each lobe with 1 intermediate and 1 small 8 -shaped pore. Medial anal plate 50 [ 45â€“50 ] Âµm long, 50 [ 60 ] wide; generally with a slightly serrate apex. Anal ring with 4 pairs of setae, each about 80 [ 105â€“110 ] Âµm long.

Venter. Medium-sized pores, each
10 x
5.0â€“ 5.5 [
8 x
5â€“6 ] Âµm, in a fairly narrow marginal band and also present sparsely across posterior abdominal segments and very sparsely around mouthparts. Simple pores similar to those on dorsum but sparse. Small bilocular pores, each about
5 x
4 [
5 x
4.5 ] Âµm, present medially on head and thorax. Spiracular disc-pores small, each 3.0â€“5.0 Âµm wide (largest near apex of band) with mainly 5 loculi but sometimes 6 at apex of band, sparse in narrow bands extending onto dorsum, each band narrowing to about 1 pore wide near margin and hardly, if at all, expanding at apex; each band with a total of about 50 pores; posterior band appears to bifurcate as usual but more anterior branch quickly becomes obsolete laterally, but posterior branch as above; each apex usually with 2 [ 1 or 2 ] minute 8 -shaped pores + 1 or 2 larger setae; also with 3â€“8 [ 4â€“7 ] disc-pores near each antenna. Small convex closed pores, each 3â€“4 Âµm wide and 3 Âµm tall, present in groups on either side of each spiracle and in a very sparse band between each antenna and metathoracic leg stub, as follows: 1 or 2 between antenna and anterior spiracle; a group of 9â€“11 [ 6â€“18 ] just anterior to anterior spiracle; a group 3â€“5 [ 5â€“11 ] posterior to each anterior spiracle; 4â€“6 [ 2â€“11 ] anterior to each posterior spiracle; 5â€“7 [ 1â€“7 ] posterior to each posterior spiracle, and 4 [ 1â€“6 ] associated with each metathorac leg stub. Multilocular disc-pores, each about 7 Âµm wide with mainly 10 loculi, distributed as follows:
VIII 3
or 4 [ 1â€“4 ] on each side;
VII 9â€“10
[ 8â€“13 ] on each side; and then in lines across segments:
VI 4
or 5 [ 5â€“10 ] submarginally + 36 [ 45â€“60 ] medially;
V 9
or 10 [ 6â€“12 ] submarginally + 49 [ 48â€“58 ] medially;
IV 5
or 6 [ 9â€“15 ] submarginally + 19 [ 37â€“46 ] medially;
III 2
[ 3â€“6 ] submarginally + 18 [ 7â€“17 ] medially, II a total of 10 [ 3â€“8 ] on each side; metathorax with a line of 1â€“3 laterad to leg stub + 0â€“4 medially [ 2â€“6 , mainly laterad to leg stub], 2 or 3 [ 2â€“4 ] near each mesothoracic leg, and 1 near each anterior spiracle [ 0â€“2 ]. Tubular ducts similar to those on dorsum but shorter and narrower, present throughout. Ventral setae sparse, setose and mainly about 5 Âµm long; preanal setae each 50 [ 70â€“75 ] Âµm long; companion seta short. Leg stubs well developed, width of base of each metaleg 36 [ 50â€“60 ] Âµm wide. Antennae apparently 2 segmented [unsegmented], each 46â€“58 [ 30â€“40 ] Âµm long, without an apical cone-like point but with a shallow setal cavity. Clypeolabral shield 132 [ 105â€“ 125 ] Âµm long. Spiracular peritremes each 35â€“40 [ 38â€“42 ] Âµm wide.

Comment. Although Malawi is a long way from Gabon , no major differences could be found between these two lots of material. The adult females of
A. gabonenesis
differ from those of all other
Antecerococcus
species in having the following combination of character-states: (i) dorsum with four sizes of 8 -shaped pore; (ii) large and intermediate-sized pores forming a swirl-like pattern; (iii) two (usually) small 8 -shaped pores present within apices of each stigmatic band; (iv) each margin of posterior abdominal segments with about 20 large 8 -shaped pores; (v) cribriform plates in submedial groups of 3â€“6 on each side of abdominal segment IV; (vi) leg stubs present; (vii) posterior stigmatic bands non-bifurcated; (viii) small convex closed pores in a sparse band between each antenna and metathoracic leg, plus concentrations near each spiracle; (ix) multilocular disc-pores present across all abdominal segments but most abundant on segments IV-VI; also present across metathorax; (x) antennae without a distinct cone-like apex or setal cavity.
Antecerococcus gabonensis
is somewhat similar to
A. oumeensis
, described as new below, but differs in having the small convex closed pores on the venter near each spiracle.

The adult female of
A. gabonensis
falls within Group A in the key to species of
Antecerococcus
, keying out close to
A. keralae
,
A. ornatus
and
A. kurraensis
.
